The base class for all builders.

Naive Builder

A naive tree builder.

This builder uses a naive algorithm to build a suffix tree using \(\mathcal{O}(n^2)\) time.

Credits: This implementation closely follows the description in [Gusfield1997] Chapter §5.4, page 93.

class suffix_tree.naive.Builder(tree, id_: object, path: suffix_tree.util.Path)

Builds the suffix-tree using a naive algorithm.

build() → None

Add a string to the tree.

Ukkonen Builder

A tree builder that uses Ukkonen’s Algorithm.

Ukkonen’s algorithm to build a suffix tree in linear time adapted to generalized suffix trees.

In a generalized suffix tree the start and end indices \(k\) and \(p\) are not enough to uniquely identify a subsequence, we also need to keep track which sequence \(k\) and \(p\) are referring to. So instead of using the three parameters \(s, (k, p)\) we use the two parameters s and path, with path being a structure containing the string, \(k\), and \(p\).

We also have two problems with indices: The first is that Python indices start with 0 while Ukkonen’s start with 1. The second is that Python indices point to one beyond the end while Ukkonen’s point to the end. In conclusion: Ukkonen’s 1..2 becomes Python’s [0:2].

See also: Ukkonen’s suffix tree algorithm in plain English https://stackoverflow.com/questions/9452701/

class suffix_tree.ukkonen.Builder(tree, id_: object, path: suffix_tree.util.Path)

Builds the suffix-tree using Ukkonen’s Algorithm.

__init__(tree, id_: object, path: suffix_tree.util.Path)
transition(s: suffix_tree.node.Internal, k: int) → tuple[suffix_tree.node.Node, suffix_tree.util.Path]

Let \(g'(s,(k',p')) = s'\) be the \(t_k\)-transition from \(s\).

return \(s', path'\)

test_and_split(s: suffix_tree.node.Internal, path: suffix_tree.util.Path, t: collections.abc.Hashable) → tuple[bool, suffix_tree.node.Internal]

Test if endpoint and eventually split a transition.

Return True, if s is the end point.

“Tests whether or not a state with canonical reference pair \((s, (k, p))\) is the end point, that is, a state that in \(STrie(T^{i-1})\) would have a \(t_i\)-transition. Symbol \(t_i\) is given as input parameter \(t\). The test result is returned as the first output parameter. If \((s, (k, p))\) is not the end point, then state \((s, (k, p))\) is made explicit (if not already so) by splitting a transition. The explicit state is returned as the second output parameter.” — [Ukkonen1995]

canonize(s: suffix_tree.node.Internal, path: suffix_tree.util.Path) → tuple[suffix_tree.node.Internal, suffix_tree.util.Path]

Canonize a reference pair.

r”Given a reference pair \((s, (k, p))\) for some state \(r\), it finds and returns state \(s'\) and left link \(k'\) such that \((s', (k', p))\) is the canonical reference pair for \(r\). State \(s'\) is the closest explicit ancestor of \(r\) (or \(r\) itself if \(r\) is explicit). Therefore the string that leads from \(s'\) to \(r\) must be a suffix of the string \(t_k\dots t_p\) that leads from \(s\) to \(r\). Hence the right link \(p\) does not change but the left link \(k\) can become \(k', k' \gte k\).” — [Ukkonen1995]

update(s: suffix_tree.node.Internal, path: suffix_tree.util.Path) → tuple[suffix_tree.node.Internal, suffix_tree.util.Path]

Update the tree.

“[…] transforms \(STree(T^{i-1})\) into \(STree(T^i)\) by inserting the \(t_i\)-transitions in the second group. The procedure uses procedure canonize mentioned above, and procedure test-and-split that tests whether or not a given reference pair refers to the end point. If it does not then the procedure creates and returns an explicit state for the reference pair provided that the pair does not already represent an explicit state. Procedure update returns a reference pair for the end point \(s_{j'}\) (actually only the state and the left pointer of the pair, as the second pointer remains \(i - 1\) for all states on the boundary path).” — [Ukkonen1995]

\(s,(k,i - 1)\) is the canonical reference pair for the active point.

Returns

a reference pair for the endpoint \(s_{j\prime}\).

build() → None

Add a string to the tree.

Gusfield Builder

A tree builder that uses Gusfield’s variant of Ukkonen’s algorithm.

Credits: This implementation of Ukkonen’s algorithm in Python closely follows the description in [Gusfield1997] Chapter 6, 94ff.

See also: the implementation in C by Dan Gusfield et al.: http://web.cs.ucdavis.edu/%7Egusfield/strmat.html

See also: Ukkonen’s original paper: http://www.cs.helsinki.fi/u/ukkonen/SuffixT1withFigs.pdf

class suffix_tree.ukkonen_gusfield.Builder(tree, id_: object, path: suffix_tree.util.Path)

Builds the suffix-tree using Gusfield’s Algorithm.

suffix_link_dance(node: suffix_tree.node.Node, beta: suffix_tree.util.Path) → suffix_tree.node.Internal

Go to the parent, follow the suffix link and do the skip/count trick.

For a description see: [Gusfield1997], page 100

build() → None

Add a string to the tree.
